passages.text: Europe Multi- Industry: Food for Thought: Global data points, end- market commentary and latest research
What's worked in Multi- Industry recently: Machinery underperformed Electricals stocks by 102bps this week.

Key Multi- Industry notes: Europe Multi- Industry: Sector themes in focus/Datamap in Pictures/Quick post summer thoughts on capital goods; Halma Plc: Brownline acquisition showcases continued focus on M&A; Accelleron first take.

Recent global read- across: US: Durable Goods Orders/New Home Sales/LIRA/Mortenson Construction Cost Index; China: Industrial Profits/Property Weekly Wrap; Japan - Industrial Production/Construction/Komtrax data/Automation; Australia: Construction Activity.
Links to our GS Capex Tracker, Europe Multi- Industry: Data Map and our latest report on Revisiting estimates and Multis Toolkit screens.

Machinery underperformed Electricals stocks by 102bps this week. The top five performers this week were: FLS (7.4%), Prysmian (3.9%), SKF (2.8%), NKT (2.8%) and Wartsila (2.5%). The bottom five performers this week were: Carel (- 4.8%), Alstom (- 4.3%), Accelleron (- 4.1%), Ariston (- 2.5%) and GVS (- 2.4%).

USA: Durable Goods Orders Above Expectations; Consumer Confidence Declines Slightly; Boosting Q3 GDP Tracking Estimate to \(+1.8\%\) : Durable goods orders decreased by \(2.8\%\) in July, above expectations for a larger decline. Core capital goods orders increased by \(1.1\%\) , above expectations for a slight increase, and June growth was revised up by 0.2pp to \(- 0.6\%\) . Core capital goods shipments increased by \(0.7\%\) , above expectations. The consumer confidence index declined slightly less than expected in August. More here.

USA: NewHome Sales Decline in July but Revised Up for June; Boosting Q3 GDPPacking Estimate to \(+1.6\%\) : New home sales declined in July, against consensus expectations for an increase, but the June growth rate was revised up. We boosted our Q3 GDP tracking estimate by 0.1pp to \(+1.6\%\) (quarter- over- quarter annualized). Our Q3 domestic final sales estimate stands at

Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA in the U.S.
\(+0.4\%\) . More here.
US Leading Indicator of Remodeling Activity (LIRA) shows improvement: US LIRA shows signs of improvement at \(1.8\%\) in 2Q2025 vs \(0.4\%\) in 1Q2025.

US: Mortenson Construction Cost Index: Nationally, nonresidential construction costs tracked by the Mortenson Quarterly Cost Index for the second quarter of 2025 rose by \(+2.72\%\) over the past quarter and \(+5.42\%\) over the previous twelve months. All Mortenson regional offices reported cost increases this quarter.

China: Industrial profits rose sequentially in July; August PMI preview: China's industrial profits fell by \(1.1\%\) yoy, while revenue rose by \(1.0\%\) yoy in July (vs. \(- 4.4\%\) yoy and \(+1.5\%\) yoy in June). In sequential terms, industrial profits increased by \(3.2\%\) sa non- annualized (vs. \(+6.5\%\) in June), while revenue decreased by \(0.3\%\) sa non- annualized (vs. \(+0.2\%\) in June). More here.

China Property Weekly Wrap: Shanghai announced partial HPR relaxation and other stimulus; transactions improved modestly: New homes sales volume on average was \(+18\%\) wow and \(- 6\%\) yoy with tier- 2 and Central Western outperforming, while new home search activities fell \(0.8\%\) wow. Secondary transactions on average were \(+6\%\) wow and \(+3\%\) yoy, with weaker price appreciation expectations from both agents and homeowners. More here.

Japan: July Production Falls Sharply, Below Market Forecast; Retail Sales Also Falls MOM, Below Market Forecast: Industrial production fell by \(- 1.6\%\) mom in July, turning down again after rising for the first time in three months in June by \(+2.1\%\) . The market forecast was for a decline of \(- 1.1\%\) . Shipments declined for the second consecutive month, by \(- 2.5\%\) (June: \(- 0.8\%\) ). Inventories rose by \(+0.8\%\) (June: \(- 0.3\%\) ), turning up for the first time in four months. The government maintained its overall assessment of industrial production as "see- sawing." More here.

Japan Machinery: Construction: July 2025 trade statistics: Total mini excavator exports in July came to \(\yen 28.2\) bn \((- 9\%\) yoy, \(+8\%\) mom), with total export volume of 6,188 units \((- 7\%\) yoy, \(+5\%\) mom). Total hydraulic excavator exports in July came to \(\yen 73.3\) bn \((+36\%\) yoy, \(- 2\%\) mom), with total export volume at 4,451 units \((+39\%\) yoy, \(- +3\%\) mom). More here.

Japan: Komtrax data: Komtrax Utilisation Hours Japan at \(1.2\%\) in Jul- 25 vs \(- 0.9\%\) in Jun- 25/North America at \(4.9\%\) in Jul- 25 vs \(- 0.3\%\) in Jun- 25/Europe at \(- 1.3\%\) in Jul- 25 vs \(0.0\%\) in Jun- 25.

Japan Machinery: Automation: July robot/Robodrill volume inferred from customs data: The Ministry of Finance announced trade data (customs data) during morning trading on August 28. We use this data as an indicator of volume trends for Fanuc's (Sell) robots and Robodrill No. 30 vertical machining centers, and Yaskawa Electric's (Neutral) robots. Japanese companies have a large share of the global robot market and high domestic production ratios. Since Japan accounts for the majority of global robot production, we believe export volume trends from Japan to the rest of the world can be viewed as an indicator of investment in robots and automation, mainly in the auto and electronics industries. More here.

Australia: Construction activity rises more than expected: Construction activity increased \(+3.0\%\) qoq in 2Q2025, above expectations for a more modest increase (GSe: \(+0.4\%\) qoq; BBG: \(+0.0\%\) qoq). The rise was driven by a surge in private non- residential construction \((+13.5\%\) qoq), while residential investment was little changed in the quarter \((0.1\%\) qoq). More here.
Exhibit 1: US Wholesale Trade-Durables, Electrical Inventory/Sales fell sharply and is now close to historical lows 3m rolling MoM change \(+5\) bps and 12m rolling MoM change -10 bps
Source: Census Bureau, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Europe Multi- Industry: Sector themes in focus: In this presentation, we focus on the European Multi- Industry's latest trends and provide an overview of the sector overall, including the Multi- industry Toolkit screen, capex environment, capacity utilization levels, inventories, pricing levels, tariff impact, China competition and German policies. More here.

Europe Multi- Industry: Datamap in Pictures: August 2025: The Europe Multi- Industry Datamap tracks \(>800\) high frequency indicators across end markets and geographies. These data points indicate the pulse of the respective end markets and offer a potential readacross for the companies we cover. More here.

Europe Capital Goods: Quick post summer thoughts on capital goods: Capital goods has outperformed the STOXX600 YTD, but in particular over the last 3 months, as investors have become more confident on a German recovery and on

lower risk of tariff headwinds than initially feared. It is now trading at a \(25\%\) premium on 12m forward PE to the STOXX600, significantly above the premium it has traded at over the long run. This suggests the market seems to be confident of solid growth ahead, but we think the bar is high particularly in the next 6 months for capital goods. More here.

Halma Plc: Brownline acquisition showcases continued focus on M&A: On 26th Aug, Halma announced the completed acquisition of Brownline B.V., a provider of advanced gyroscopic locating systems used in underground drilling, for €150m cash (c.£129m). This places the deal among the group's top three acquisitions by consideration to date and showcases Halma's continued focus on M&A, a central pillar of the group's growth strategy that we reviewed at length in our 6th August initiation note. With this acquisition, Halma has committed c. £2bn of capital across 95 acquisitions over the last 20 years, funded out of FCF. More here.

Accelleron Industries: 1H25 release, cut margin guidance despite earlier positive release: We expect Accelleron consensus earnings estimates to move down MSD on the back of the margin guidance cut, all else equal. Accelleron had significantly increased their FY25 revenue guidance on July 15th and maintained margin guidance, driving c. \(7\%\) consensus adj EBITDA move upwards since. More here.

China and Japan Machinery Export Tracker: Jul 2025 update: North America joined DM recovery; EM strength broadly sustained: In this July 2025 update, we highlight the notable inflection in North America (value wise), which along with sustained Europe recovery points to a likely more broader- based DM cycle inflection. For EMs, the strength generally sustained except for Middle East. For this month, China and Japan export value growth started to converge (+c. \(30\%\) yoy). More here.

We, Daniela Costa, Christian Hinderaker, CFA, Meihan Yang, Aditya Agarwal, Susmita Saha, Tommaso Nocchi, Aayush Kandpal and Hollie Cooper, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.
